Blonde: A Depressing Disservice to an Already Misunderstood Figure

14/10/2022

Louise Cresswell deconstructs the controversial Marilyn Monroe biopic

Image by Netflix

By Lawrence Mason

When I first learned that Netflix would be releasing a biopic about Marilyn Monroe starring Ana de Armas, an actress whose talent I feel has been criminally underutilised in recent productions, I was thrilled. Monroeâ€™s life is notably cinematic, from the depths of her tragedy to the heights of her success, to the point where one wonders why an ambitious portrayal of her complex character hasnâ€™t been attempted in this format before Andrew Dominik took the helm, as both screenwriter and director. However, my excitement was unsurprisingly dampened by the negative critical feedback that erupted before the filmâ€™s premiere.

Now, I normally take negative film criticism with a pinch of salt. I am a staunch opponent of googling the Rotten Tomatoes score of any movie, and as someone who has never formally studied film, I am more than happy to sit down and watch pieces that are probably poorly made in a technical sense if I feel that I will enjoy them. Despite this, â€˜negative critical reviewâ€™ is quite frankly a flattering description of the zeitgeist that preceded Blondeâ€™s premiere. It is not so much that the film has been panned - it received mixed reviews - it is more so that the film has kickstarted an incredibly divisive discourse about the ethics of creating heavily fictionalised accounts of the lives of real people. It is based on the book of the same name written by Joyce Carol Oates, who herself has reviewed the film favourably, describing it asâ€œutterly feministâ€.

How anyone can conclude that Blonde is a feminist production, is completely and totally beyond me. In my personal view, the misogyny of this film manifests itself twofold. It is sexist firstly in the overtness of its misogyny. I know this sounds stupid,: but bear with me. Throughout the film, Marilyn, whose real-life name was â€˜Norma-Jeanâ€™, is brutalised, condescended, minimised, assaulted, and demeaned by every single man she encounters. This is hard to watch, as the film is not only two hours and forty-six minutes long, but Marilyn is also one of only two prominent female characters in the film, the other being her mother, who also brutalises and assaults her.

I typically love dark cinema and am known to ardently recommend Darren Aronofskyâ€™s Requiem For A Dream, one of the most relentlessly depressing films ever produced, to anyone who will listen. Blonde, however, is relentlessly depressing in an extremely different way, namely because it is so profoundly sad to watch someone be hurt so deeply, to cry and scream for so long, without any real â€˜pointâ€™ being made as to why her trauma is so constant. The film does not attempt to insinuate that there are traits exhibited by Marilyn that the men in her life were attracted to exploit, nor does it make any wider critique about the mediaâ€™s objectification of women, or even at the most obvious possible level, touch upon the awful treatment women were subjected to in the mid 20th Century. Instead, it does appear as if Marilynâ€™s worst fears are true, that she inspired a unique and damning explosion of the worst facets of the human condition in everyone she encounters, without penetrating what accepted social standards may have led to the wider world feeling that they were entitled to use and dispose of her at will.

The other way in which Blonde is sexist is ironically in its attempt to condemn sexism toward Marilyn Monroe. Norma-Jeanâ€™s real life, the one in which she was a victim of child sexual abuse and domestic violence, owned like property by a film studio and forced into productions that she wanted no part of for a fraction of the financial return her peers received, was clearly deemed not entertaining enough for Oates. When penning â€˜Blondeâ€™, she wrote in an innumerable amount of additional assaults and toxic love affairs than actually occurred in Norma-Jeanâ€™s already fraught personal life. These write-ins are graphically depicted throughout the film from the offset, occasionally interspersed with a montage of Marilyn being haunted by the ghost of her abortion (which, again, was an act of creative license on the part of Oates and Dominik, as no abortion was ever known to have taken place). The Marilyn character is still a sexist caricature of a woman - although she may not be the femme fatale sex object of the 1950s, she is now the perfect woman for a director with a Madonna-Whore complex, repeatedly depicted in highly erotically-charged environments yet always completely against her will, never once complicit in her own sexualisation. The cherry on top - throughout the film Marilyn is so bereft by the absence of her father that she refers to all of her lovers as â€œDaddyâ€.

Blonde does have its merits. It is beautifully shot, contains a stellar cast, and features exemplary performances from de Armas and particularly Adrien Brody, whom I feel really embodied the awkwardness of Arthur Miller. The montage where the pair re-enact the famous post-marriage shot of Monroe and Miller is genuinely startling in its likeness to the real pictures. However, this one-minute scene does not warrant subjecting yourself to all three hours of the film, which made me so deeply unhappy that I was compelled to write a 900-word film review about it.
